answer_html: \(\int_{0}^{\pi/6}\frac{5\cos \theta d\theta }{\sqrt{(5)^2-(5)^2(\sin\theta)^{2}}}=\frac{\pi}{6}\) Since this is a definite integral, the result is a number and we do not need to return to the previous variables.
answer_latex:
$\int_{0}^{\pi/6}\frac{5\cos \theta d\theta }{\sqrt{(5)^2-(5)^2(\sin\theta)^{2}}}=\frac{\pi}{6}$ Since this is a definite integral, the result is a number and we do not
need to return to the previous variables.
hints_html: The identity \(\displaystyle {}\sin^2\theta+\cos^2\theta=1\) may be useful here.
hints_latex:
The identity $\displaystyle {}\sin^2\theta+\cos^2\theta=1$ may be useful
here.
hints_raw: The identity <math>\displaystyle{}\sin^2\theta+\cos^2\theta=1</math> may be useful here.
question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
We start by noting that the denominator is in the form

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}a^2-x^2\end{aligned}\]

with a = 5. This is a good indicator that we want to do a trig substitution with

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}x=a\sin\theta\end{aligned}\]

because

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}a^2\sin^2\theta+a^2\cos^2\theta=a^2\end{aligned}\]

and hence

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{} a^2 - a^2\sin^2\theta = a^2\cos^2\theta\end{aligned}\]

We will use this identity to handle the square root in the denominator. So, let

\[\begin{aligned} x&=5\sin\theta\\ dx&=5\cos \theta d\theta.\end{aligned}\]

We must also modify the limits of integration since we have a new variable. When

\[\begin{aligned} x&=0=5\sin\theta\end{aligned}\]

solving for \(\theta\) gives \(\displaystyle {}\theta=0\). Solving

\[\begin{aligned} x&=5/2=5\sin\theta\end{aligned}\]

for \(\theta\) gives \(\displaystyle {}\theta=\frac{\pi}{6}\). Substituting these values into our integral we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{5/2}\frac{dx}{\sqrt{25-x^{2}}} = \int_{0}^{\pi/6}\frac{5\cos \theta d\theta }{\sqrt{25-(5\sin\theta)^{2}}} = \int_{0}^{\pi/6}\frac{5\cos \theta d\theta }{\sqrt{(5)^2-(5)^2(\sin\theta)^{2}}}.\end{aligned}\]

We can use the identity above we get

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{\pi/6}\frac{5\cos \theta d\theta }{\sqrt{(5)^2-(5)^2(\sin\theta)^{2}}} = \int_{0}^{\pi/6}\frac{5\cos \theta d\theta }{\sqrt{(5)^2(\cos\theta)^{2}}} = \int_{0}^{\pi/6} 1 d\theta = \frac{\pi}{6}\end{aligned}\]

Since this is a definite integral, the result is a number and we do not need to return to the previous variables.
sols_raw:
We start by noting that the denominator is in the form

:<math>
\displaystyle{}a^2-x^2
</math>

with ''a = 5''. This is a good indicator that we want to do a trig substitution with

:<math>
\displaystyle{}x=a\sin\theta
</math>

because

:<math>
\displaystyle{}a^2\sin^2\theta+a^2\cos^2\theta=a^2
</math>

and hence
:<math>
\displaystyle{} a^2 - a^2\sin^2\theta = a^2\cos^2\theta
</math>

We will use this identity to handle the square root in the denominator. So, let

:<math>
\begin{align}
x&=5\sin\theta\\
dx&=5\cos \theta d\theta.
\end{align}
</math>

We must also modify the limits of integration since we have a new variable. When 

:<math>
\begin{align}
x&=0=5\sin\theta
\end{align}
</math>

solving for <math>\theta</math> gives <math>\displaystyle{}\theta=0</math>. Solving

:<math>
\begin{align}
x&=5/2=5\sin\theta
\end{align}
</math>

for <math>\theta</math> gives <math>\displaystyle{}\theta=\frac{\pi}{6}</math>. Substituting these values into our integral we obtain

:<math>
\int_{0}^{5/2}\frac{dx}{\sqrt{25-x^{2}}} = \int_{0}^{\pi/6}\frac{5\cos \theta d\theta }{\sqrt{25-(5\sin\theta)^{2}}} = \int_{0}^{\pi/6}\frac{5\cos \theta d\theta }{\sqrt{(5)^2-(5)^2(\sin\theta)^{2}}}.
</math>

We can use the identity above we get

:<math>
\int_{0}^{\pi/6}\frac{5\cos \theta d\theta }{\sqrt{(5)^2-(5)^2(\sin\theta)^{2}}} = \int_{0}^{\pi/6}\frac{5\cos \theta d\theta }{\sqrt{(5)^2(\cos\theta)^{2}}} = \int_{0}^{\pi/6} 1 d\theta = \frac{\pi}{6}
</math>

Since this is a definite integral, the result is a number and we do not need to return to the previous variables.
